metadata.case_name: M/s J. Burman Co. v. Union of India

facts.text: Respondent Union of India advertised in Indian Trade Journal for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of coconut oil.

Appellant submitted tender No. SM-I/1104524, which was accepted by respondent on August 31, 1949, forming a contract governed by general conditions of contract Form W.S.B. 133, including arbitration agreement.
Disputes arose regarding the contract and were referred to two arbitrators appointed by the parties in pursuance of the arbitration agreement.
After considerable arbitration proceedings, appellant objected to arbitrators' jurisdiction claiming no concluded contract between parties.

Respondent filed petition in Court of First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi under ss. 33 and 28 of Arbitration Act against appellant, seeking declaration of concluded contract containing valid arbitration agreement and extension of time for arbitrators.
Appellant pleaded no concluded contract, no jurisdiction in court under s.28, and traversed other allegations.
Trial judge framed issues, found concluded contract proved, valid arbitration agreement, court jurisdiction, declared valid reference, granted one month's extension to arbitrators.
No specific point raised by appellant in pleadings that court had no jurisdiction under s.33 or s.32.
Appellant filed Civil Revision Application No. 135-D of 1957 in Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi, challenging trial court decision.
High Court confirmed trial court's finding of concluded contract with arbitration agreement, held petition competent under ss.28 and 33, dismissed revision.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

Acceptance letter dated August 31, 1949: 'Your offer is hereby accepted... subject to your depositing 10 as security... The contract is concluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt.'

General conditions Form W.S.B. 133, Clause 4(a): On acceptance of tender, contractor shall deposit security at option of Secretary within specified period. Clause 4(b): Failure to deposit constitutes breach.
Arbitrators heard matter at length, proceedings reached stage for award when appellant raised no contract plea, refused to apply under s.33, causing stalemate.

legal_issues.text: Construction of ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, particularly whether court has jurisdiction to entertain petition by party affirming existence/validity of arbitration agreement.
Whether there was a concluded contract between the parties, given acceptance letter's 'subject to your depositing 10 as security' clause.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial court had no jurisdiction to entertain respondent's petition under ss.33 and 28 as s.33 applies only to challenges to existence/validity, not affirmations; s.32 bars suits but provides no remedy for affirmers.
No concluded contract as acceptance letter made security deposit a condition precedent via 'subject to your depositing 10 as security', varying general conditions where it was condition subsequent.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Contract Act s.7; requires absolute unqualified acceptance

respondent_arguments.text: Concluded contract existed via acceptance of tender, governed by Form W.S.B. 133 including valid arbitration agreement; petition competent under ss.28 and 33.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.32 and 33 bar suits on existence/validity of arbitration agreement; s.33 for challengers only; affirmers can apply under court's inherent jurisdiction implied by s.32 and per s.31, avoiding anomaly of no remedy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of ss.31-33 to prevent abuse via suits, channel disputes to petitions in specified courts.

court_reasoning.text: Petition in substance seeks declaration on arbitration agreement existence/validity, as challenge to main contract common to both; arbitration clause distinct yet enforceable separately.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Substance over form; if no contract, no arbitration agreement.

court_reasoning.text: Acceptance letter read as whole is absolute unqualified acceptance per s.7 Contract Act; 'subject to' clause reminder of subsequent condition per Form W.S.B.133 Cl.4(a)(b), not precedent; contract concluded thereby.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tender per general conditions; letter by govt officer, states 'contract is concluded by this acceptance'.

holdings.text: Court has jurisdiction under inherent powers per ss.31,32 to entertain application affirming existence/validity of arbitration agreement; petition competent.
Concluded contract exists between parties containing valid arbitration agreement.

precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitration clause distinct from other contract clauses, specifically enforceable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Gulamali Abdulhussain Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya
precedents_cited.relevance: Court has inherent jurisdiction to entertain petitions barred by s.32 affirming arbitration agreement.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit not barred if not merely challenging arbitration agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars suits on existence/validity/effect of arbitration agreements/awards; provides for petitions; jurisdiction for affirmers implied; extension of time.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Acceptance must be absolute and unqualified.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court and trial court's findings that the trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the petition and that a concluded contract containing a valid arbitration agreement existed between the parties.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; prior relief of declaration and extension upheld for respondent.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding any law for the time being in force, no suit shall lie on any ground whatsoever for a decision upon the existence, effect or validity of an arbitration agreement or award..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.32, central to jurisdiction issue.

key_quotes.text: "The contract is concluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key phrase in acceptance letter showing concluded contract.

key_quotes.text: "a party affirming the existence of an arbitration agreement cannot apply under s. 33 for obtaining a decision that the agreement in question exists."
key_quotes.speaker: court
